text:
Make a Prediction

  • What are the minimum number of cuts need to make each shape from a square prism.

Conduct an Experiment

Equipment:

  • Modeling clay
  • Clay wire cutter or plastic knife

Directions:(individually, with a partner, or small group)

  • Shape the clay into a square prism.
  • Make the minimum number of cuts to create a

- triangular prism,

- pentagonal prism, and

- hexagonal prism

  • Make a sketch of the cuts needed to make the shape.

Analyze the Data

  • Describe the minimum number of cuts needed to make each shape.

Answers will vary. Possible answers include:

A triangle prism (view from the top of the prism)

  • One vertical cut that passes through opposite vertices of the square top will form two congruent triangular prisms. The red line in the diagram shows cutting from the square top.

tiles.title: Top view of cutting a triangle prism

text:
A pentagonal prism (view from the top of the prism)

  • One vertical cut that takes off a “corner” of the square top will produce a pentagonal prism (but not a regular pentagonal prism). The red line in the diagram shows cutting from the square top.

tiles.title: Top view of cutting a pentagonal prism

text:
A hexagonal prism (view from the top of the prism)

  • Two vertical cuts that take off “corners” of the square top will produce a hexagonal prism (but not a regular hexagonal prism). The red lines in the diagram shows cutting from the square top.

tiles.title: Top view of cutting hexagonal prisms
